page.title: 10SHRAWARDINE CASTLE
page.content: Little now remains of this once active castle. The original castle was built in the{Norman}style. The Motte and Bailey were recorded in the original Domesday book in 1086. The castle was of importance in the eleventh century, during the English - Welsh border warfare. The castle stands 50 feet above the River Severn and 30 feet above ground level. Today there are fragments of the square keep and Motte, but the site is mainly rubble. Any masonry which does remain is probably Twelfth Century as the castle had to be re-built at that time. As an{Ancient Monument}the castle remains are open to the public via a footpath, but the owners of the land, Mr & Mrs Hill, would appreciate being asked. They live in the nearby farmhouse.
